metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: In the example from the previous page, we used the pointer variable to get the memory address of a variable (used together with the & reference operator). However, you can also use the pointer to get the value of the variable, by using the * operator (the dereference operator):
content.html: In the example from the previous page, we used the pointer variable to get the memory address of a variable (used together with the & reference operator). However, you can also use the pointer to get the value of the variable, by using the * operator (the dereference operator):

syntaxHighlighting.text:
string food = "Pizza";  // Variable declarationstring* ptr = 
    &food;    // Pointer declaration// 
    Reference: Output the memory address of food with the pointer (0x6dfed4)cout << 
    ptr << "\n";// 
    Dereference: Output the value of food with the pointer (Pizza)cout << 
    *ptr << "\n";

// 
    Reference: Output the memory address of food with the pointer (0x6dfed4)

// 
    Dereference: Output the value of food with the pointer (Pizza)

content.code:
string food = "Pizza";  // Variable declarationstring* ptr =
&food;    // Pointer declaration//
Reference: Output the memory address of food with the pointer (0x6dfed4)cout <<
ptr << "\n";//
Dereference: Output the value of food with the pointer (Pizza)cout <<
*ptr << "\n";

syntax_highlighting.text:
string food = "Pizza";  // Variable declarationstring* ptr = 
    &food;    // Pointer declaration// 
    Reference: Output the memory address of food with the pointer (0x6dfed4)cout << 
    ptr << "\n";// 
    Dereference: Output the value of food with the pointer (Pizza)cout << 
    *ptr << "\n";

// 
    Reference: Output the memory address of food with the pointer (0x6dfed4)

// 
    Dereference: Output the value of food with the pointer (Pizza)

content.code_html:
string food = "Pizza";  // Variable declaration
string* ptr = &food;    // Pointer declaration

// Reference: Output the memory address of food with the pointer (0x6dfed4)
cout << ptr << "\n";

// Dereference: Output the value of food with the pointer (Pizza)
cout << *ptr << "\n";

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
string food = "Pizza";  // Variable declarationstring* ptr = 
    &food;    // Pointer declaration// 
    Reference: Output the memory address of food with the pointer (0x6dfed4)cout << 
    ptr << "\n";// 
    Dereference: Output the value of food with the pointer (Pizza)cout << 
    *ptr << "\n";

// 
    Reference: Output the memory address of food with the pointer (0x6dfed4)

// 
    Dereference: Output the value of food with the pointer (Pizza)

content.text: Note that the * sign can be confusing here, as it does two different things in our code:
content.html: Note that the * sign can be confusing here, as it does two different things in our code:

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
What does the following code output? string food = "Burger"; string* ptr = &food; cout << *ptr;
content.html:
What does the following code output?
string food = "Burger";
string* ptr = &food;
cout << *ptr;
